Lorem ipsum, dolor sit amet consectetur adipisicing elit. Quisquam, pariatur.

Featured Works 2008 | 2020

Meyoko aka Melissa Murillo was born in the Republic of Ecuador. Though she says that she retains many happy memories from her childhood

it was the antiquated environment she grew up in that familiarized her with the concept of death from an early age, that would one day become the main source of inspiration for her artworks.

She would spend a good majority of her days tending to her grandmother’s garden, where she would play with the farm animals they owned. When these were slaughtered in front of her, Murillo would often contemplate the meaning of their death, and watch the light drain away from their eyes.

The artist explains this to be one of the reasons she creates the majority of her characters without eyes, reflecting a deep sense of loss and passing in the fog that emanates from their horrifically exquisite faces. She also recounts how she would ponder the travels and destination of the departed souls after their demise.

The Garden of Deceitful Delights: Ballpoint pen, ink, acrylic, watercolor on paper

Nephentes: Ballpoint pen, ink, acrylic, watercolor on paper

However, her artistic metamorphosis truly began upon her arrival in Europe.

She first settled down in Paris, intent on pursuing an artistic career in the renowned city. She would visit the Louvre every first Sunday of the month and spend hours wandering the halls of the museum, admiring the vast collection of Dutch Artworks in the Passage Richelieu. When Murillo’s application to the famed Beaux-Arts Academy (L’École des Beaux-Arts) was rejected, not due to her lack of talent, but her age, she felt disillusioned. Her family didn’t support her decision to pursue an artistic career and urged her to conform to the norm.

She found herself stuck, so when a friend recommended she visits Berlin she bought a one-way train ticket, and settled down in the city, where her artistic roots would come to flourish. It didn’t take long for her endless efforts to grow fruitful, for people on platforms like Facebook and especially myspace began showing an interest in her artistic prowess.

Alecto: Ballpoint pen, ink, acrylic, watercolor on paper

Megaera: Ballpoint pen, ink, acrylic, watercolor on paper

Due to this, her artworks began being featured in renown books and magazines all around the world.

Though it felt different to be acknowledged for her art, Murillo noticed that she had less time to give to her research and creation. After some years of activity, Murillo decided to enter a hiatus, so she could finally dedicate her passion the attention it deserved.

Her time of inactivity proved beneficial. In 2017 she was fortunate enough to meet Pablo Guayasamin, the son of one of South America’s greatest Artists, Oswaldo Guayasamin. He was a prolific artist whose career arose to fame after catching the eye of Nelson Rockefeller, the grandson of the American magnate John D. Rockefeller. It was the first time Murillo had the opportunity to speak with an art collector of his caliber, whose opinion she valued not only due to his father but due to his culturally rich background and upbringing.

This encounter marked the start of a new phase in Murillo’s artistic life.

Conspiration a la Reine no.1: Ballpoint pen on paper

Euphorbe: Ballpoint pen on paper
